channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: China's astronauts land safely after space debris collision
item.description: Three Chinese astronauts are back on earth after they had to prolong their stay in outer space due to space debris hitting their spacecraft.
item.content:encoded: Three Chinese astronauts are back on earth after they had to prolong their stay in outer space due to space debris hitting their spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Emily Feng

item.title: White House pivots to affordability as President Trump confronts voter discontent
item.description: President Trump says he's going to make America affordable again. It's a pivot to focusing on the economy as voters express discontent.
item.content:encoded: President Trump says he's going to make America affordable again. It's a pivot to focusing on the economy as voters express discontent.
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith

item.title: Redistricting in Missouri revives a century-old racial fault line
item.description: A new Trump-backed voting map reopens Kansas City's racial divide along Troost Avenue.
item.content:encoded: A new Trump-backed voting map reopens Kansas City's racial divide along Troost Avenue.
item.dc:creator: Celisa Calacal

item.title: Mexico's new generation takes to the streets, accusing leaders of protecting cartels
item.description: Gen Z activists are marching in Mexico City today against what they call a narco-state, while Mexican President Sheinbaum alleges the protesters are backed by right-wing parties.
item.content:encoded: Gen Z activists are marching in Mexico City today against what they call a narco-state, while Mexican President Sheinbaum alleges the protesters are backed by right-wing parties.
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: Will air travel be back to normal before Thanksgiving?
item.description: The shutdown is over, but a 3% cut in flights remains as air traffic staffing slowly rebounds.
item.content:encoded: The shutdown is over, but a 3% cut in flights remains as air traffic staffing slowly rebounds.
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Inside the unlikely origins of NPR's Tiny Desk concerts
item.description: From a spontaneous jam to a global series, this is the story of Tiny Desk told by its creators.
item.content:encoded: From a spontaneous jam to a global series, this is the story of Tiny Desk told by its creators.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Her phone alarm still rings in Lebanon, days after an Israeli strike killed her
item.description: An Israeli air strike killed three children and their father weeks before they were due to emigrate to the U.S.
item.content:encoded: An Israeli air strike killed three children and their father weeks before they were due to emigrate to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: A new film envisions a future where reality TV turns lethal
item.description: Director Edgar Wright talks about his new film, which imagines a world where every encounter could mean death in a dark, action-packed dystopia.
item.content:encoded: Director Edgar Wright talks about his new film, which imagines a world where every encounter could mean death in a dark, action-packed dystopia.
item.dc:creator: Sacha Pfeiffer

item.title: Right-wing media shrugs off latest Epstein document release
item.description: "To me, these are nothingburgers. If they're even real," said one pro-Trump podcaster, of the thousands of documents that were released this week, including several that named the president.
item.content:encoded:
"To me, these are nothingburgers. If they're even real," said one pro-Trump podcaster, of the thousands of documents that were released this week, including several that named the president.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Shannon Bond

item.title: Major League Soccer has a new schedule to align with international leagues
item.description: MLS is switching from a spring-to-fall calendar to a summer-to-spring calendar. The move aligns with the rest of international soccer but could pose a challenge for teams in wintry locations.
item.content:encoded: MLS is switching from a spring-to-fall calendar to a summer-to-spring calendar. The move aligns with the rest of international soccer but could pose a challenge for teams in wintry locations.
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan
